data.title: Rutherford, Ernest, 1871
data.text:
Ernest Rutherford

Dates

August 30, 1871 – October 19, 1937

Authorized Form of Name

Rutherford, Ernest, 1871-1937

Additional Forms of Names

Rutherford, E. (Ernest), 1871-1937

Rutherford, Ernest, 1st Baron of Nelson, 1871-1937

Rutherford, Ernest, Baron, 1871-1937

Biography

Abstract

Ernest Rutherford was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1908, "for his investigations into the disintegration of the elements, and the chemistry of radioactive substances." Rutherford was tremendously influential in the fields of chemistry and physics; he advised many future Nobel Prize winners and significant scientists, such as James Chadwick, Niels Bohr and Otto Hahn. Throughout his career, he worked at McGill University, University of Manchester, and at the Cavendish Laboratory at the University of Cambridge.

August 30, 1871Birth, Nelson (N.Z.).

1893Obtained MA in Mathematics and Physical Science, Canterbury College, University of New Zealand, Wellington (N.Z.).

1894Awarded the 1851 Exhibition Science Scholarship and transferred to Trinity College, University of Cambridge.

1894Obtained BSc in Physical Science, Canterbury College, University of New Zealand, Wellington (N.Z.).

1897Awarded BA Research degree and the Coutts-Trotter Studentship, Trinity College, Cambridge (England).

1898MacDonald Chair of Physics, McGill University, Montréal (Québec).

1903Fellow, Royal Society.

1904Awarded the Royal Society Bakerian Medal, Royal Society.

1904Awarded the Rumford Medal, Royal Society.

1907Langworthy Professor of Physics, University of Manchester, Manchester (England).

1908Awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry "for his investigations into the disintegration of the elements, and the chemistry of radioactive substances".

1910Awarded the Barnard Medal for Meritorious Service to Science, Columbia University.

1910Awarded the Elliott Cresson Medal, Franklin Institute.

1911Theorized the structure of the atom, now called the Rutherford Model.

1913Awarded the Matteucci Medal, Italian Academy of Sciences.

1914Knighted.

1916Awarded the Hector Memorial Prize, Royal Society of New Zealand.

1919Cavendish Professor of Physics, University of Cambridge, Cambridge (England).

1920Created the term "proton," and theorized the existence of the nucleus.

1922Awarded the Copley Medal, Royal Society.

1924Awarded the Franklin Medal, Franklin Institute.

1925Awarded the Order of Merit.

1925 – 1930President, Royal Society.

1928Awarded the Albert Medal, Royal Society of Arts.

1930Awarded the IET Faraday Medal, Institution of Engineering and Technology.

1931Given the title 1st Baron Rutherford of Nelson and Cambridge.

1936Awarded the Wilhelm Exner Medal, Austrian Trade Union.

October 19, 1937Death, Cambridge (England).

Occupation

Nuclear physicist.
